questions.text: A 56-year-old male patient was taking theophylline for chronic bronchial asthma. After starting another drug for his new onset disease state, symptoms of theophylline toxicity started appearing. Which of the following is the most likely drug started for his disease?
questions.solution:
• Erythromycin is an enzyme inhibitor which inhibits theophylline metabolism and increases its plasma level precipitating its toxicity.

Mnemonic:

  • Enzyme inhibitors[Virat Kohli Can't Call Every Indian]
  • Valproate
  • Ketoconazole
  • Cimetidine
  • Ciprofloxacin/Clarithromycin
  • Erythromycin
  • INH

Option B, C & D: Phenytoin, Griseofulvin and rifampicin are cytochrome enzyme inducers and hence they increase the metabolism of theophylline causing therapeutic failure of the same.

Key Takeaway:

  • Erythromycin is an enzyme inhibitor which inhibits theophylline metabolism and increases its plasma level precipitating its toxicity.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman has a history of asthma for 10 years. She was brought to the medicine department with complaints of an acute onset of wheezing. Which of the following drugs would be the best for treatment of an acute attack of asthma?
questions.solution:
Inhaled albuterol would provide the fastest acting and most localized therapy for an acute attack.

Bronchodilators are the only drugs useful in terminating acute attack of bronchial asthma.

Adrenergic drugs (β2 agonists) act by:

Stimulating GPCRs - Activation of adenylyl cyclase - Increase in cAMP

  • smooth muscle relaxation(bronchodilation)
  • Decreases the mediator release from mast cells.
  • Inhibit microvascular leakage
  • Increase mucociliary transport by increasing ciliary activity.
  • By inhalation route, these are the fastest acting drugs.
  • Salbutamol (albuterol), metaproterenol, and terbutaline are fast acting drugs by inhalation route. They are used for aborting an attack of acute asthma.
  • Not suitable for prophylaxis because of the shorter duration of action.

Option B, C & D: All of them are orally active drugs which will take some time to act. So they are not preferred for acute emergency conditions.

Key Takeaway:

  • Inhaled albuterol would provide the fastest acting and most localized therapy for an acute attack.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman with moderately severe asthma was on multi drug treatment for her asthma. She came to the medicine department with laboratory reports of elevated liver enzymes. Her physician has thought that it could be caused by one of her medications. Which of the following drugs is most likely causing this adverse effect?
questions.solution:
Zileuton is an inhibitor of 5-lipoxygenase, and thereby decreases the biosynthesis of leukotrienes; it is associated with liver toxicity.

Zileuton:

  • It is a 5-LOX inhibitor, blocks Leukotrienes C4/D4 as well as Leukotrienes B4 synthesis.
  • It therefore has the potential to prevent all Leukotrienes induced responses
  • The duration of action of zileuton is short and it has hepatotoxic potential.

Summary of Drugs acting on Leukotrienes

Option A: Sodium cromoglycate is associated with Bronchospasm, throat irritation and cough in some patients, especially with fine powder inhalation.

Option B: Montelukast and zafirlukast inhibit the bronchoconstrictor action of LTs at cys LT1 receptor. These are used as prophylactic agents for bronchial asthma. These are very safe drugs, but few cases of Churg Strauss syndrome (vasculitis with eosinophilia) have been associated with their use.

Option D: Methylxanthine's Adverse effects are primarily referable to the g.i.t., CNS and CVS. Headache, nervousness and nausea are early symptoms. Children are more liable to develop CNS toxicity.

Key Takeaway:

  • Zileuton inhibits synthesis of LTB4 (chemotactic) and LTC4 and LTD4 (bronchoconstrictor). Limiting features of this drug are short duration of action and hepatotoxicity.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man has come to the medicine department with complaints of exercise induced bronchospasm, particularly in the cold weather. He was advised by his physician to take his medication as a prophylactic measure 15 minutes prior to anticipated exercise, which will help to prevent the asthmatic attack but does not produce bronchodilation. Which of the following drug does he take?
questions.solution:
Cromoglycate are prophylactic agents, useful especially for exercise or cold induced bronchospasm.

Option A: β2 agonists act by Stimulating GPCRs that result in the activation of adenylyl cyclase and finally increase in cAMP, which causes smooth muscle relaxation (bronchodilation).

Option C: Corticosteroids are potent anti-inflammatory drugs and also decrease bronchial hyperreactivity and mucosal edema. Anti-inflammatory action is due to decreased recruitment of inflammatory cells as well as decreased production of PGs and LTs

Option D: Omalizumab is a monoclonal antibody against circulating IgE and is indicated to prevent the attack of bronchial asthma in patients not responding to a combination of long-acting β2 agonist and a high dose of inhalational steroid.

Key Takeaway:

  • Cromoglycate are prophylactic agents, useful especially for exercise or cold induced bronchospasm.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl with asthma precipitated by seasonal pollens is receiving prophylactic twice-monthly injections of a monoclonal antibody. Which of the following mediators of asthma is antagonized by this drug?
questions.solution:
The patient is most likely taking omalizumab, a monoclonal antibody that inactivates immunoglobulin E and thereby prevents allergic asthma attacks.

Omalizumab

  • It is a humanized monoclonal antibody against IgE.
  • Administered via subcutaneous route. It Neutralizes free IgE in circulation without activating mast cells and other inflammatory cells.
  • In severe extrinsic asthma, it reduces exacerbations and steroid requirements. It's reserved for resistant asthma patients with positive skin tests or raised IgE levels who require frequent hospitalization.

Option B: Montelukast Acts via Blocking Leukotriene C4.

Option C: Cetirizine, Fexofenadine & loratadine etc drugs acts via blocking Histamine action.

Option D: Cyclosporine acts via Blocking Production of IL-2.

Key Takeaway:

  • Omalizumab is a monoclonal antibody against circulating IgE and is indicated to prevent the attack of bronchial asthma in patients not responding to a combination of long acting β2 agonist and a high dose of inhalational steroid.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man was admitted to the hospital with an acute asthmatic attack. The man had been suffering from seasonal asthma for 1 year. On history taking, he reported that he took two aspirin tablets the previous evening for a headache. A diagnosis of drug hypersensitivity was made, an appropriate therapy was instituted. Which of the following treatments would be most appropriate for his treatment and post-discharge therapy?
questions.solution:
Leukotriene inhibitors and antagonists have demonstrated the important role of leukotrienes in aspirin-induced asthma.

Some asthmatic patients are very sensitive to aspirin as well as to all nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, and even small doses can cause profound bronchoconstriction, flushing, and abdominal cramping.

Key Takeaway:

  • Leukotriene inhibitors and antagonists have demonstrated the important role of leukotrienes in aspirin-induced asthma.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man is being treated for severe asthma. He was brought to the emergency department following an episode of life-threatening tachycardia requiring emergency treatment. Which drug is most likely responsible for this adverse effect?
questions.solution:
• Formoterol is a long-acting β2-agonist that may cause tachycardia and increase mortality in asthmatic patients.

β2 Agonists

Salmeterol → Slow acting → Only used for prophylaxis

Formoterol → Fast acting → Used for acute attacks also

Adverse Effects of β 2 Agonists:

T - Tachycardia

T - Tremors (Most common side effect)

T - Tolerance (Mainly with long-acting beta 2 agonists)

T - T wave changes (Because of hypokalaemia)

These drugs can cause hyperglycaemia (but never hypoglycemia)

Option B: Ipratropium may occasionally cause tachycardia, the drug is poorly absorbed after inhalation and is less likely to cause severe tachycardia than are β2-agonists.

Option A & D: Budesonide, cromolyn are even less likely to cause tachycardia.

Key Takeaway:

  • Formoterol is a long-acting β2-agonist that may cause tachycardia and increase mortality in asthmatic patients.

questions.text: A 17-year-old patient is brought to medicine department with complaining of chronic cough that gets quite severe at times and is beginning to interfere with his studies. He has a history of having allergy to lot of things. Which of the following would be the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
• This is a fairly classical presentation of asthma, which should be confirmed with further pulmonary testing.
  • Mild persistent asthma can be treated in several ways but inhaled glucocorticoids are very effective.

Option A: Oral prednisone has many side effects, especially in a young person.

Option B: Omalizumab is for patients who are refractory to other treatments and those with allergies.

Option C: Antihistamines such as diphenhydramine are poorly effective in asthma

Key Takeaway:

  • Inhaled glucocorticoids are very effective in Mild persistent asthma

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman having a history of asthma, is recovering from a myocardial infarction is on several medications including low dose aspirin. She complains of large bruises on her arms and legs and some fatigue. A standard blood panel reveals markedly elevated alanine aminotransferase (ALT). Which of the following is most likely responsible for the increase in liver enzymes?
questions.solution:
• Zileuton is a leukotriene synthesis inhibitor that can cause increases in hepatic enzymes and altered liver function.
  • It decreases the rate of heparin metabolism, leaving patients prone to easy bruising.

Zileuton:

  • It is a 5-LOX inhibitor, blocks Leukotrienes C4/D4 as well as Leukotrienes B4 synthesis.
  • It therefore has the potential to prevent all Leukotrienes induced responses
  • The duration of action of zileuton is short and it has hepatotoxic potential.

Zafirlukast and albuterol are antiasthmatic agents but do not alter liver enzymes.

Aspirin might cause bleeding disorders, but the low dose this patient is taking is unlikely to be responsible for the liver enzyme abnormalities.

Option A: The major adverse effect of heparin is bleeding, which is treated with fresh frozen plasma. Specific antidote of heparin is protamine

Option C: Zafirlukast inhibits the bronchoconstrictor action of LTs at cys LT1 receptor. This is used as prophylactic agents for bronchial asthma.

These are very safe drugs but few cases of Churg-Strauss syndrome (vasculitis with eosinophilia) have been associated with their use.

Option D: Muscle tremor and tachycardia are the major side effect of β2 agonists

Key Takeaway:

  • Zileuton is a leukotriene synthesis inhibitor that can cause increases in hepatic enzymes and altered liver function.

questions.text: For which of the following conditions Leukotrienes inhibitors are most suitably used?
questions.solution:
Aspirin Induced Asthma:

Aspirin acetylates the COX-2 enzyme

↓

Converts arachidonic acid to 15-HETE (15-hydroxyeicosatetraenoic acid).

↓

In WBCs, 15-HETE is converted to epi-lipoxins (15-epi-LXA4 or 15-epi LXB4).

↓

These are aspirin-triggered lipoxins - Powerful bronchoconstrictors

↓

Induction of Aspirin Induced Asthma

Key Takeaway:

  • Leukotriene inhibitors and antagonists have demonstrated the important role of leukotrienes in aspirin-induced asthma.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient had mild bronchial asthma. After consultation with pulmonologist he was prescribed a combination medicine via inhalation route given in a figure below. After some days of taking the medicine he presented to otorhinology department with oral thrush/canidiasis. Which of the following antifungal is the most suitable for its treatment?
questions.solution:
• As patient was receiving inhalational glucocorticoid, he was developed oropharyngeal candidiasis as side effect.
  • Clotrimazole is the most commonly used topical imidazole effective in the treatment of tinea infections like otomycosis and oral/cutaneous/vaginal candidiasis.
  • For oropharyngeal candidiasis 10 mg troche of clotrimazole is allowed to dissolve in the mouth 3-4 times a day
  • Adverse effects of Inhalational Corticosteroids
    1. Hoarseness of voice (Dysphonia)
    2. Oral candida (oral thrush): opportunistic infection

ORAL THRUSH

  • Oral thrush can be prevented by:
    1. Water gargles after each inhalation.
    2. Use plastic spacer
    3. Ciclesonide: no candidiasis. It is a prodrug. It becomes activated by esterases only in lung.
  • Treatment of oral thrush: Anti-fungal drugs
    1. Nystatin paint/gargle
    2. Cotrimazole for superficial infection
    3. Tablet Fluconazole for deep oropharynx infection.

Key Takeaway:

  • Clotrimazole is the most commonly used topical imidazole effective in the treatment of tinea infections like oral candidiasis

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy with a long term history of asthma was admitted to the hospital for evaluation. The patient complained of increasing respiratory difficulty and frequent awakening from at night. Present medications were high-dose inhaled fluticasone and salmeterol. Pulmonary function testing indicated a forced expiratory volume (FEV1) 30%, and laboratory exams showed fivefold high serum immunoglobulin E (IgE) level of 615 IU/mL. Which of the following would be appropriate to add to the patient's treatment at this time?
questions.solution:
• Omalizumab is effective in reducing asthma exacerbations and also reduce inhaled & oral dosage requirement for glucocorticoids in patients with severe asthma
  • As the patient is already on inhaled glucocorticoids and also have five fold rise in serum IgE levels, adding omalizumab would be most appropriate thing to do

Omalizumab

  • It is a humanized monoclonal antibody against IgE.
  • Administered via subcutaneous route
  • Neutralizes free IgE in circulation without activating mast cells and other inflammatory cells.
  • In severe extrinsic asthma, it reduces exacerbations and steroid requirement.
  • Reserved for resistant asthma patients with positive skin tests or raised IgE levels who require frequent hospitalization.

Option A & B: Patient was already taking β2 agonists and inhaled glucocorticoids. So adding other of these groups will not get the benefits.

Option C: Zileuton is not effective in resistant asthma.

Key Takeaway:

  • Omalizumab is a monoclonal antibody against circulating IgE and is indicated to prevent the attack of bronchial asthma in patients not responding to combination of long acting β2 agonist and a high dose of inhalational steroid.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of having COPD was given intravenous aminophylline therapy by his physician. Following taking the prescribed medicine the patient developed diuresis. This action is mediated by which of the following mediator/receptor?
questions.solution:
Key Takeaway:

  • Methylxanthines are mild diuretics. They act by inhibiting tubular reabsorption of Na+ and water as well as increased renal blood flow and g.f.r.

questions.text: A 16-year-old female with severe persistent asthma is placed on multiple medications. She has been taking her medications as instructed, but one of the Medicine is causing her to have tachycardia, nausea, and jitteriness. She has been informed of the need to measure serum levels of this medication. Which medication is responsible for the above given undesirable side effects?
questions.solution:
• The methylxanthine agent is given in asthma because of its prominent bronchodilatory effect.
  • These agents have a low therapeutic index and often can cause adverse effects.
  • Narrow therapeutic index drug has low safety of margin. Hence, it requires monitoring of blood levels - Therapeutic drug monitoring.
    • Normal therapeutic range: 5-15 mg/dl
    • It is degraded by CY1A2.

Side effects:

Mnemonic [DSP having Nausea]

  • Diuresis
  • Seizures.
  • Palpitation and arrhythmias
  • Nausea/vomiting/diarrhea
  • Pulsatile headache.

Option A: Ipratropium bromide is a short acting inhaled anticholinergic bronchodilator, administered as aerosol, they produce minimal antimuscarinic side effects due to poor systemic absorption.

Option B: Montelukast and zafirlukast are very safe drugs; produce few side effects like abdominal pain, headache and rashes

Option C: Zileuton (Lipoxygenase inhibitor) inhibits synthesis of LTB4 (chemotactic) and LTC4 and LTD4 (bronchoconstrictor). Limiting features of this drug are short duration of action and hepatotoxicity.

Key Takeaway:

  • Methylxanthines directly stimulate the heart and increase the force of myocardial contractions. They tend to increase heart rate

questions.text: A 49-year-old man with a 15-year history of 2-pack a day smoking comes to the medicine OPD complaining of difficulty in breathing with wheezing. Later he diagnosed as having chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and prescribed inhaled tiopropium twice a day. He returns 6 months later with quit smoking, but still complaining of having about 1 episode of serious shortness of breath per day. Which of the following medicine should be added to his existing treatment?
questions.solution:
• Roflumilast is a fairly specific PDE4 inhibitor, useful to decrease exacerbations in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

Roflumilast

  • It has been approved for symptomatic treatment of COPD (but not bronchial asthma).
  • It exerts anti-inflammatory action, primarily in the lungs.
  • Roflumilast appears to be a promising treatment option for moderate-to-severe cases of COPD.
  • Most common adverse effect is diarrhoea.
  • New bronchodilators were developed which are specific PDE4 inhibitors & approved for treatment of COPD.
    • Roflumilast
    • Cilomilast
    • Ibudilast

Option A & C: Oral glucocorticoids such as dexamethasone pose serious risks when used chronically and inhaled glucocorticoids are not recommended in early-stage COPD although they might be of benefit to patients with severe disease.

Option D: Zileuton is ineffective in COPD.

Key Takeaway:

  • Roflumilast appears to be a promising treatment option for moderate-to-severe cases of COPD.

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman with a long history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease was admitted to the hospital for an acute exacerbation of her disease. The patient's medications on admission were inhaled ipratropium and oral theophylline. Which of the following molecular actions on bronchial smooth muscle most likely contributed to the broncho dilating effect of theophylline in this patient?
questions.solution:
• The broncho dilating action of methylxanthine seems to be primarily due to inhibition of phosphodiesterase enzymes, mainly phosphodiesterase 4 (PDE4).

The inhibition of phosphodiesterase 4 (PDE4)

↓

Rise in the intracellular concentrations of

  • cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP)
  • cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP)

↓

Smooth muscle relaxation.

Key Takeaway:

  • Bronchodilatation, cardiac stimulation and vasodilatation occur and mediator release is inhibited when cAMP level rises in the bronchial/cardiac/vascular smooth muscle and in inflammatory cells, respectively due to Inhibition of phosphodiesterase (PDE)

questions.text: A 59-year-old man with a long history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease recently had theophylline added to his therapeutic regimen. Which of the following actions most likely occurred during the first days of the new therapy?
questions.solution:
Methylxanthines stimulate gastric secretion, which can explain the abdominal discomfort that frequently occurs after the administration of theophylline.

  • Methylxanthines enhance secretion of acid and pepsin in stomach, even on parenteral injection.
  • They are also gastric irritants-theophylline more than caffeine.
  • Methylxanthines produce opposite effects by Blockade of adenosine receptors
  • Adenosine acts as a local mediator in CNS, CVS and other organs.
  • Adenosine cause following changes by stimulating its respective receptors:
    • Contraction of smooth muscles, especially bronchial;
    • Dilates cerebral blood vessels,
    • Depresses cardiac pacemaker and
    • Inhibits gastric secretion.

Key Takeaway:

  • Methylxanthines enhance secretion of acid and pepsin in the stomach, even on parenteral injection. They are also gastric irritants

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) was diagnosed with an upper respiratory tract infection, and erythromycin was prescribed. Her COPD was reasonably well controlled on oral theophylline and inhaled albuterol. Which of the following would be an appropriate change in the patient's therapeutic regimen at this time?
questions.solution:
• Erythromycin has been reported to inhibit the cytochrome P450 mediated metabolism of several drugs, including theophylline.
  • Because theophylline has a narrow therapeutic index, it is appropriate to decrease the dosage of the drug for the duration of the erythromycin therapy to avoid overdose toxicity.

Mnemonic

Enzyme inhibitors [Virat Kohli Can't Call Every Indian]

  • Valproate
  • Ketoconazole
  • Cimetidine
  • Ciprofloxacin/Clarithromycin
  • Erythromycin
  • INH

Key Takeaway:

  • Erythromycin has been reported to inhibit the cytochrome P450 mediated metabolism of several drugs, including theophylline.
  • Hence dose of theophylline has to be reduced so as to avoid toxicity.

choices.text: Supports bactericidal activity against Pseudomonas aeruginosa
Releases nitric oxide from airway epithelium
Depolymerizes the DNA of purulent airways secretions
Stimulates the cystic fibrosis transmembrane regulator

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl with a long history of cystic fibrosis presented to the hospital because of the worsening of respiratory symptoms. An appropriate therapy was prescribed that included inhaled dornase alfa. Which of the following best explains the mechanism of action of dornase alfa in the patient's disease?
questions.solution:
DNAse (dornase alfa) depolymerizes the DNA of purulent airways secretions & reduces mucus viscosity in sputum of patients with cystic fibrosis.

  • It is indicated if there is significant symptomatic and lung function improvement after a trial of therapy.
  • The principal source of DNA in the sputum of cystic fibrosis patients is from the nuclei of degenerating neutrophils that accumulate in the lung because of chronic bacterial infections.
  • DNA is the principal factor that increases the viscosity of the sputum in these patients.
  • Dornase alfa is a recombinant human deoxyribonuclease that is administered by inhalation.
  • It degrades the DNA, which has been shown to significantly decrease the viscosity of the sputum, thus reducing obstruction and the severity of respiratory infections.

Key Takeaway:

  • Dornase alfa depolymerizes the DNA of purulent airways secretions & reduces mucus viscosity in sputum of patients with cystic fibrosis.

choices.text: They are indicated in COPD only for severe/advanced cases
Instituted early they retard the progression of COPD
Their use predisposes to respiratory infections
Instituted early they offer symptomatic relief in COPD

questions.text: A 67-year-old male patient came to pulmonologist seeking treatment for uncontrolled severe asthma due to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). His pulmonologist was in opinion to add an inhalational glucocorticoid to existing regimen. Which of the following is the correct statement about the use of inhaled glucocorticoids in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)?
questions.solution:
Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)

  • The airway inflammation in COPD is not very responsive to corticosteroids.
  • As such, only high dose ICS is beneficial in advanced COPD with frequent exacerbations.
  • They should not be used in early/mild cases. There is no proof that they retard progression of COPD.

Adverse effects:

  • Hoarseness of voice
  • Dysphonia
  • Sore throat
  • Asymptomatic or symptomatic oropharyngeal candidiasis (most common side effects)

Key Takeaway:

  • High dose Inhalational corticosteroids are beneficial in advanced COPD with frequent exacerbations.
